terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa prairie. Moderate elevation with prairie scenery. Ultra-endurance format.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Iowa ultra-endurance event. Prairie terrain with good access, moderate costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Spotted Horse Ultra is a regional ultra-endurance event in Iowa—150 miles of prairie terrain. The Iowa prairie is nice and organization is solid, but the heat, moderate terrain, and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid Iowa prairie ultra-endurance race. Worth it for Midwest riders. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in the Midwest—yes, it's solid. If you're international—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar ultra-endurance: Trans Iowa.

logistics.food: Iowa has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: 150 miles requires months of ultra-endurance preparation.
Iowa summer heat requires heat adaptation.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional ultra-endurance event with prairie terrain.

logistics.explanation: Race director Sarah Cooper allows camping on her front lawn at her house "appropriately off a gravel road," though Adrienne Taren noted "the appropriate amount of swearing at iPhone Maps" to find it. The self-supported format eliminates aid stations but routes riders past Casey's convenience stores at miles 38, 69, 100, and 138. Weather-forced course reroutes happen last-minute—Friday rains "forced a couple of re-routes before the race started" in 2018.

length.explanation: 150 miles pushes into serious ultra territory, with HP Ultra Cycling packing "enough food to fuel me for 20 hours of racing" for the 200-mile option. Scott's navigation error added 30 miles to his day, turning 180 into an 18-hour ordeal that nearly broke him. Distance options from 70 to 200 miles accommodate different suffering tolerances, with Kate Geisen noting the unsupported format meant "just you and the C-store shelves." Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: Iowa's Level B roads define the technical challenge—barely maintained farm tracks that turn unrideable when wet. Scott on his fat bike "was able to ride probably more than most" but still walked most of the 3-5 mile B-road sections. In 2018, Adrienne Taren found a rider "poking at his very, very muddy bike with a stick" after the "fat bike" became unrideable through ankle-deep mud. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Kate Geisen encountered "a virtual gravel wall" climb where she was "pretty excited to make it to the top without having to walk." The 8000 feet of elevation gain over 150 miles comes through Iowa's rolling terrain—constant ups and downs rather than epic climbs. Scott noted riding "careening down at 30 mph and others I was climbing at 2mph which is a feat of itself just to keep balance." Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Mid-October Iowa weather swings violently, as the 2018 race proved with severe attrition. Adrienne Taren reported that "the second I hit the Iowa border, the rain-pocalypse broke loose. Also, the temperature dropped 20-some degrees." The 2019 start was delayed 40 minutes for thunderstorms with lightning, while recent years saw "extremely dusty" conditions with 30 mph wind gusts. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Iowa farmland means zero altitude considerations. You're starting around 1000 feet and staying in similar elevation throughout the rolling countryside. No acclimatization needed, no thin-air excuses available—your suffering comes from distance and elevation gain, not oxygen deprivation. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Self-supported navigation through unmarked Iowa farm roads creates real adventure without wilderness risk. Scott encountered wildlife throughout: "I saw too many deer, rabbits, raccoon, possum and a few cats in this dark-thirty stretch." Two farm dogs followed him for 5-7 miles each, "having a ball." The remote course offers solitude—elite finisher noted you're "free to ride all day long" with just the sunrise as your companion.

prestige.explanation: Regional Iowa event with limited national recognition outside gravel circles. The 120-rider cap keeps it intimate but invisible—Kate Geisen noted "not being a regular to the Iowa gravel scene, I saw few familiar faces." HP Ultra Cycling's reference to race director Sarah Cooper as "one of your heroes" reflects respect within ultradistance circles rather than mainstream gravel media attention.

race_quality.explanation: Severe weather creates organizational challenges—2018 saw only 22 of 57 starters finish the 150-mile distance after hypothermic conditions and course reroutes. The bare-bones approach works for self-sufficient riders but offers zero safety net. Scott noted "by Checkpoint #1, the race had already claimed a few derailleurs and hypothermic conditions forced many others to drop."

experience.explanation: 150 miles through Iowa's rolling hills delivers suffering without the circus. The 'odyssey through serene landscapes' marketing actually undersells the real experience—8000 feet of climbing over farm roads where your only company is corn and your own thoughts. It's pure, unfiltered gravel racing stripped of everything but the essential hurt.

community.explanation: Race director Sarah Cooper earns fierce loyalty from riders who camp on her front lawn and bond "over bicycles and whether or not we were going to die in a thunderstorm." Volunteers provide unexpected roadside support—Adrienne Taren noted "perfectly normal to have a friendly stranger stick a Reese's inside your mouth for you because your hands are too filthy." The intimate field creates shared suffering bonds among "the handful of other crazy people."

field_depth.explanation: Regional Iowa field of weekend warriors and corn country crushers, not national talent. Scott's casual training approach—"30 minutes to an hour" rides for a month before attempting 200 miles—suggests recreational rather than competitive focus. The 120-rider cap and Iowa location naturally limits participation to regional riders and ultradistance masochists rather than drawing competitive depth from national gravel scene. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Entry fees unavailable in research, but the no-frills approach suggests typical Iowa pricing well under $150. Race director allows free lawn camping at her house, eliminating lodging costs for hardy riders. The self-supported format means zero aid station expenses passed to riders, though it dumps all nutrition costs on participants. Value proposition centers on pure distance suffering without expensive race production overhead.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $150-200. Winterset's proximity to Des Moines keeps flights reasonable but requires rental car for the 30-mile drive. Free camping option at race director's house eliminates lodging costs for tent-capable riders, though small Iowa towns offer limited hotel competition. Scott's fat bike setup and Adrienne's cold-weather gear highlight equipment needs for Iowa's unpredictable October conditions and muddy Level B roads that destroy standard gravel setups. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Ep. 117 Kelsi and Cole Ledbetter and the Iowa Gravel Project
videos.description:
Kelsi and Cole Ledbetter are the founders of the Iowa Gravel Project and Redfield Rock and Roll Gravel Race in Iowa. They recently took over a couple of Midwest classics: The Spotted Horse Ultra and the Iowa Gravel Classic. I was curious what led them down the road to not host just one gravel race, but now three, as well as the weekly rides with the Iowa Gravel Project. Information can be found online as well as instagram and facebook: 
Iowa Gravel Project and the Redfield Rock and Roll Gravel Race: https://www.iowagravelproject.com/
Iowa Gravel Classic: https://iowagravelclassic.com/
https://www.instagram.com/iowagravelclassic/
Spotted Horse Ultra:  https://spottedhorsecycling.com/
https://www.instagram.com/spottedhorsecycling/?hl=en

We would love it if you would consider supporting Bike Talk with Dave by rating, reviewing and sharing on your favorite podcast platform. We'd invite you to support the show financially at www.buymeacoffee.com or on Venmo @David-Mable. You'll receive a Bike Talk with Dave sticker! Bikeiowa.com is the online host of Bike Talk with Dave. Get your event listed on the extensive ride and race calendar for free! Create an account and add and edit your event to reach thousands of cyclists. Register for the core4 today! New distances in 24 include a 20, 40, 60 or 100-mile option. Register at www.core4.bike
Follow Bike Talk with Dave on Instagram at https://www.instagram.com/biketalkwithdave/ and Facebook so you don't miss any of the fun, and you can now find every episode on your computer at www.biketalk.bike. And now available on YouTube on the Bike Talk with Dave YouTube channel!
And if you need any digital media work: photography, videography and editing, podcast production and editing, look no further than Mable Media. Connect at www.mablemedia.net to help grow your brand and connect with your audience!

videos.title: Friday Fives Ep. 19 Sept 25th 2020
videos.description:
Join Scott from BIKEIOWA.com to hear about what's on his radar in the Iowa cycling scene this weekend. #FridayFives is a new series for Summer 2020 and we plan to share fun destinations, events and happenings each week.

For Week #19 it is:

#1) The Weather
The (nice) weather is what's on Scott's radar! As the cooler Fall temps move in, Scott is spending all the time he can riding and camping.

Check out the 5 events on Sat on the BIKEIOWA event calendar
- 2020 Fall Family Fun Ride - trail ride in Des Moines
- RAGBRAI Roadshow - Cedar Valley Nature Trail in Marion
- Tour de Maples in Osage
- University of Okoboji Oktoberfest - a Party Ride in Arnold's Park, IA

#2) October Events
We wanted to call out some October Events. There is still plenty to do!
Oct 3 -
- Buffalo 105 in Newton
- Snaggy Ridge 105 in Tipton
- Volga City Gravel Race in Volga
- RAGBRAI Roadshow - High Trestle Trail in Slater
- CITA Dirty Duathlon *CANCELED*
- Ride Across Iowa in a Day (RAID) *CANCELED*
Oct 9
- Jingle Cross Festival & UCI World Cup *CANCELED*
Oct 10
- RAGBRAI Roadshow - Great Western Trail in Cumming
Oct 17
Joe Mann Memorial Ride in Muscatine
Fatober Fat & Mountain Bike Trail Ride in Osage
RAGBRAI Roadshow - Neal Smith Trail in Des Moines
ICGravel **canceled**
Oct 24
Spotted Horse Gravel Ultra - 2020 in St. Charles

Thanks to all the event coordinators period. We know it has been a tough decision to still hold your event let alone attend one in this strange year.  If you cancelled, we know that decision was tough too and if you chose to still have your event, we know that is stressful and we support you too.

#3) State and County Parks
Scott loves staycations. State Parks are a perfect place to get away from it all and not travel too much. You’ll be amazed at the varying terrain and topography that Iowa has to offer.

Last week we took a 4 day weekend in NE Iowa and camped, rode, hiked and found some gnarly gravel roads and scenic byways to drive on including the Great River Road along the Mississippi including a @cCassville Car Ferry ride across the river.

Find a state park at https://www.iowadnr.gov/Places-to-Go/State-Parks/Iowa-State-Parks
And county parks  at https://www.mycountyparks.com

#4) RIP - Paul Black
On Sept 23rd, a pillar in the Central Iowa cycling community - Paul Black was in his mid-70's and had done about every type of endurance race out there. Scott gives some highlights of Paul's racing pedigree an talks about his LIFE Experiences on a bicycle. 

Here are 4 memorable quotes about Paul
Kyle Robinson said "Heaven’s cycling team just received a ringer."
Sarah Cooper stated “Paul was having epic adventures and ultra racing long before it was cool, “
@Patrick Coughlin said "a lion in sheep's clothing"
Harry Fortney said "Paul was one of the good guys. He would wait for you on group rides so he could tear your legs off again. He’d always help his teammates and others be better cyclists and people in general. He was a role model, always looking for his next adventure.

No word on Funeral arrangements yet. I assume it will be a family-only event with covid, but you can read the updates on https://caringbridge.org/visit/paulblack

RIP Paul Black.

#5) Pogie Lites
As the weather gets cooler, Scott mentions Pogie Lites - a product he created in 2018 after enduring a really rainy and cold 2017 race season. He got tired of cold wet hands and being on the verge of hypothermia so he made a few prototypes which lef to Pogie Lites which are a 4-season super-lite-weight, water-resistant, wind-proof pogie that keeps the wind, rain and muck off your hands.
Pogie Lites allow YOU to control the temperature of your hands.

How to get them?
They are $75 a pair and you can get them at
https://pogielites.com
World of Bikes in Iowa City and Beaverdale Bicycles in Des Moines both have a small supply
Goldfinch Cyclery in Cedar Rapids will have a supply in a week,
As the old saying goes “There is no such thing as bad weather, only bad gear”

THAT’S IT FOR THIS WEEK ! You can find more information on all of these items by checking out BIKEIOWA.com.

Starting in October, we’ll go from weekly posts to monthly posts. 
We’ve had fun with these weekly Summer posts and plan to post weekly again next Spring.
 
We’ll let ya know a couple of days in advance when we’ll go LIVE so you can tune.  We’ll still add to YouTube and BIKEIOWA as a Review afterwards too so if you miss it, you can still watch it later.

If YOU have something you’ve like us to share on Friday Fives ping us on Facebook or email Biker@BIKEIOWA.com

RIDE SAFE and Stay Healthy !

quotes.text: What is spotted horse known for? It's a race in October, it's in Iowa, and what are they known for? Well they're known for challenge - like serious challenge, like hike a bike 3 miles through 2 ft of mud challenge, like end up in a Casey putting doughnut bags on your feet so you don't freeze to death challenge.

Temperatures were in the high 60s with winds blowing between 15-35 miles per hour... almost 13 miles in, had to walk the really first big hill because yeah, it's part of life. Into the headwind for 2 and a half miles going north, going to be a lot of this going forward.
